questions.question_text: What is the engine model number for the Cessna 172M ('Mike' model)?
What is the engine horsepower rating for a Cessna 172N ('November' model)?
In a Cessna 172M ('Mike' model) with standard tanks, what is the total USABLE fuel capacity?
What is the total USABLE fuel capacity of a Cessna 172 equipped with long-range tanks?
What is the maximum certificated takeoff weight for a Cessna 172M/N in the Normal Category?
What is the maximum certificated takeoff weight for a Cessna 172M/N in the Utility Category?
What is the total oil capacity (sump and system) of the Lycoming O-320-E2D engine in the Cessna 172M?
What is the Never Exceed Speed (Vne) for the Cessna 172M/N?
What is the Maximum Structural Cruising Speed (Vno)?
What is the Maximum Flap Extended Speed (Vfe)?
What does the upper limit of the white arc on the airspeed indicator signify?
What does the lower limit of the white arc on the airspeed indicator signify?
options: Stalling speed in the clean configuration (Vs)
Stalling speed in the landing configuration (Vso)
questions.correct_answer: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (Vso)

questions.question_text: The green arc on the airspeed indicator represents the normal operating range. What does its upper limit represent?
What is the maximum window open speed for the Cessna 172N?
What is the maximum combined weight capacity for baggage area 1 and 2?
What is the horsepower rating of the Lycoming O-320-E2D engine in a Cessna 172M?
What is the maximum engine speed for the Cessna 172M/N?
What is the maximum allowable oil pressure?
What is the minimum allowable oil pressure?
What is the maneuvering speed (Va) for a Cessna 172M/N at 2300 lbs?
What is the best glide speed with flaps up?
What is the first step in the checklist for an engine fire during start on the ground?
In the event of an engine failure in flight, what is the first recommended action?
What is the significance of the yellow arc on the airspeed indicator?
options: Operations must be conducted with caution and only in smooth air
questions.correct_answer: Operations must be conducted with caution and only in smooth air

questions.question_text: What is the total fuel capacity (not usable) of a Cessna 172N with standard tanks?
In the event of an electrical fire in flight, what is the first action?
What is the recommended entry speed for a steep turn?
What is the maximum weight allowed in baggage area 2 (station 108-142) alone?
What is the correct initial procedure if an engine fire develops in flight?
options: Increase airspeed to blow out the fire
Mixture to IDLE CUT-OFF, Fuel Selector OFF, Master Switch OFF
Descend to a lower altitude and enrich the mixture
Turn on carburetor heat and open the cowl flaps
questions.correct_answer: Mixture to IDLE CUT-OFF, Fuel Selector OFF, Master Switch OFF

questions.question_text: What is the maximum flap setting recommended for a precautionary landing with engine power?
What is the wingspan of the Cessna 172M/N?
What is the wing area of a Cessna 172M/N?
What is the engine model number for the Cessna 172N ('November' model)?
Which of the following best describes the engine type in the Cessna 172M/N?
What is the minimum propeller diameter allowed for the McCauley propeller?
What is the minimum grade aviation fuel specified for the C-172 M/N?
What is the total, non-usable fuel quantity in a C172M with standard tanks?
What oil type is used for the first 25-50 hours of operation (break-in period)?
options: MIL- L-6082 Aviation Grade Straight Mineral Oil
questions.correct_answer: MIL- L-6082 Aviation Grade Straight Mineral Oil

questions.question_text: What is the total oil capacity (sump + system) for a Cessna 172N?
What is the normal operating range for oil pressure?
What is the maximum static RPM range during a run-up?
What is the first action in the 'Engine Failure Immediately After Takeoff' checklist?
During an in-flight engine failure, after establishing glide speed, what is the next memory item?
For an emergency landing without engine power, what is the last action to be performed just prior to touchdown?
When ditching in high winds and heavy seas, how should you orient your approach?
options: At a 45-degree angle to the wind

questions.question_text: If an engine fire on the ground during start fails to extinguish after cranking, what is the immediate next action after the engine fails to start?
For an engine fire in flight, after securing the engine and master switch, what is the initial target airspeed?
What is the first action for a wing fire?
options: Perform a side slip to keep flames away from the fuselage

questions.question_text: What is the power loading for the Cessna 172M/N?
What is the specified propeller ground clearance?
What is the maneuvering speed (Va) at a weight of 1600 pounds?
According to the emergency checklist, what is the best glide speed with flaps down?
In the 'Forced Landings' checklist, what is the first step?
What is the recommended approach power setting when ditching the aircraft?
What is the first step in securing the engine if an engine fire on the ground fails to extinguish after cranking?
What is the specified height of the Cessna 172?
What is the wheelbase dimension of the landing gear?
What is the wing loading of the Cessna 172?
What is the maximum propeller diameter for the McCauley 1C160/DTM7553?
What is the color of 100/130 Low Lead AVGAS?
What is the total fuel capacity (not usable) of a Cessna 172M with standard tanks?
What is the total fuel capacity of a Cessna 172 with long-range tanks?
What type of oil must be used after the first 50 hours or when oil consumption has stabilized?
options: MIL- L-6082 Aviation Grade Straight Mineral Oil

questions.question_text: For an ambient temperature of 10°C (50°F), what is a recommended oil viscosity?
What is the oil sump capacity for a Cessna 172N ('November' model)?
What is the maximum useful load for a Skyhawk II in the normal category (November model)?
What is the maximum useful load for a Skyhawk II in the utility category (Mike model)?
What is the maneuvering speed at 1950 pounds?
What does the red line on the airspeed indicator signify?
Abrupt use of controls is prohibited above what speed?
What is the airspeed for a precautionary landing with engine power?
During an engine failure on takeoff roll, after idling the throttle and applying brakes, what is the next step?
During an in-flight engine restart attempt, after selecting Carb Heat ON and Fuel Selector to BOTH, what is the next step?
What is the recommended flap setting for a forced landing without engine power?
During a precautionary landing with power, after the initial fly-over, what should you do?
options: Retract flaps upon reaching a safe altitude and airspeed
questions.correct_answer: Retract flaps upon reaching a safe altitude and airspeed

questions.question_text: During a ditching, what is the first recommended action?
During a ditching, what is the final action before touchdown?
If an engine starts after a fire during cranking, what should you do?
options: Power to 1700 RPM for a few minutes, then shut down and inspect
Power to idle and inspect for damage
questions.correct_answer: Power to 1700 RPM for a few minutes, then shut down and inspect

questions.question_text: During an electrical fire in flight, after turning off the Master and Avionics switches, what is the next step?
What is the first step for a cabin fire?
What is the pressure for the oleo strut mentioned in the notes?
The acronym 'ABCDE' from the notes stands for Airspeed, Best field, Checklist, _____, and Execute.
The POH sections mentioned in the notes include Section 3 - Emergency Procedures and Section 7 - _____
What is the maximum demonstrated crosswind component for the Cessna 172?
The electrical system in a 1978 Cessna 172N is a:
In a Cessna 172, what is the primary purpose of the fuel selector valve's 'BOTH' position?
options: For takeoff, climb, landing, and maneuvers
Used to balance fuel load in cruise
questions.correct_answer: For takeoff, climb, landing, and maneuvers

questions.question_text: For a normal landing in a Cessna 172, what is a typical final approach speed range with full flaps?
What does a continuous discharge shown on the ammeter during flight indicate?
If you experience a vacuum system failure in IMC, which two instruments will become unreliable?
options: Turn Coordinator and Vertical Speed Indicator

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the carburetor heat control?
options: To increase engine power during takeoff
To prevent or melt carburetor ice
To lean the fuel-air mixture at high altitudes
To cool the engine during prolonged climbs
questions.correct_answer: To prevent or melt carburetor ice

questions.question_text: When applying carburetor heat, what effect should be observed on the engine's RPM?
What is the maximum RPM drop allowed during a magneto check?
What is the maximum allowable RPM differential between the left and right magnetos during a run-up check?
What type of propeller is standard on a Cessna 172M/N?
What is the flap setting for a balked landing (go-around)?
The stall warning horn is designed to activate at what speed range above the actual stall?
What is the definition of 'Reference Datum' in the context of weight and balance?
options: The center of the main landing gear
The tip of the propeller spinner
An imaginary vertical plane from which all horizontal distances are measured
The rearmost point of the aircraft fuselage
questions.correct_answer: An imaginary vertical plane from which all horizontal distances are measured

questions.question_text: What is the maximum load factor (flaps up) for a Cessna 172N in the Normal Category?
What is the maximum load factor (flaps up) for a Cessna 172N in the Utility Category?
What is the purpose of the fuel strainer drain?
options: To check for proper fuel octane
To remove any water and sediment from the fuel system
questions.correct_answer: To remove any water and sediment from the fuel system

questions.question_text: How many fuel sumps are there to be drained during a preflight on a standard Cessna 172M/N?
options: One, at the lowest point of the fuselage
Three, one under each wing tank and one for the fuel strainer
Five, two under each wing and one for the fuel strainer
Two, one under each wing root
questions.correct_answer: Five, two under each wing and one for the fuel strainer

questions.question_text: What type of landing gear does the Cessna 172 have?
How are the brakes actuated on a Cessna 172?
options: Electrically via a switch on the yoke
Hydraulically via master cylinders connected to the pilot's rudder pedals
Mechanically via cables connected to a hand lever
questions.correct_answer: Hydraulically via master cylinders connected to the pilot's rudder pedals

questions.question_text: What is the function of the mixture control?
options: To control the amount of air entering the carburetor
To control the fuel-to-air ratio entering the cylinders
To select which fuel tank is being used
To prime the engine before starting
questions.correct_answer: To control the fuel-to-air ratio entering the cylinders

questions.question_text: Leaning the mixture during cruise flight at altitude results in:
options: Increased fuel consumption and lower engine temperatures
Decreased fuel consumption and higher engine temperatures
Better engine cooling and increased power
Lower fuel consumption and optimal engine performance
questions.correct_answer: Lower fuel consumption and optimal engine performance

questions.question_text: If the alternate static source is used, what effect does this have on the airspeed indicator and altimeter readings?
options: Both will read lower than actual
Both will read slightly higher than actual
Airspeed will read higher, altimeter will read lower
Airspeed and altimeter will be unaffected
questions.correct_answer: Both will read slightly higher than actual

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the manual primer?
options: To inject fuel directly into the fuel strainer for cleaning
To inject fuel directly into the cylinder intake ports for starting
To add oil to the fuel for lubrication
To remove air from the fuel lines
questions.correct_answer: To inject fuel directly into the cylinder intake ports for starting

questions.question_text: What is the recommended procedure for a soft-field takeoff?
options: Use 20 degrees of flaps and keep the nose wheel on the ground as long as possible
Use 10 degrees of flaps, hold back pressure to lift the nosewheel off early, and lift off at the lowest possible airspeed
Use no flaps and perform a high-speed taxi before rotation
Use full flaps and climb at Vx
questions.correct_answer: Use 10 degrees of flaps, hold back pressure to lift the nosewheel off early, and lift off at the lowest possible airspeed

questions.question_text: What is the recommended procedure for a soft-field landing?
options: Land at a higher speed to ensure positive control
Use minimal flaps and land flat
Use full flaps, land at the slowest possible airspeed, and keep the nose wheel off the ground as long as possible
Apply brakes immediately upon touchdown to minimize rollout
questions.correct_answer: Use full flaps, land at the slowest possible airspeed, and keep the nose wheel off the ground as long as possible

questions.question_text: What is the flap operating range (white arc)?
What is the normal operating range (green arc)?
What is the caution range (yellow arc)?
What is the best rate of climb speed (Vy) at sea level?
What is the best angle of climb speed (Vx) at sea level?
What is the primary difference between Vs1 and Vso?
options: Vs1 is the stall speed with flaps up, Vso is with flaps down
Vs1 is the stall speed at gross weight, Vso is at minimum weight
Vs1 is the stall speed in a turn, Vso is in level flight
Vs1 is the stall speed with power on, Vso is with power off
questions.correct_answer: Vs1 is the stall speed with flaps up, Vso is with flaps down

questions.question_text: What is the power source for the magnetos?
options: They are engine-driven and self-contained, requiring no external electrical power
questions.correct_answer: They are engine-driven and self-contained, requiring no external electrical power

questions.question_text: Why is it important to check that the ignition switch is OFF during the pre-flight inspection?
options: To prevent accidental starting of the engine if the propeller is moved
To allow the GPS to acquire satellites
questions.correct_answer: To prevent accidental starting of the engine if the propeller is moved

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Master Switch'?
options: It only controls the ignition system
It controls all the lights on the aircraft
It is a split switch that controls the main battery and the alternator
questions.correct_answer: It is a split switch that controls the main battery and the alternator

questions.question_text: What is the indication of a failed alternator?
options: A positive reading on the ammeter
A negative (discharge) reading on the ammeter
The engine RPM will decrease significantly
questions.correct_answer: A negative (discharge) reading on the ammeter

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the circuit breakers in the electrical system?
options: To act as on/off switches for all equipment
To protect electrical circuits from overloads
To regulate voltage from the alternator
To increase the amperage to certain components
questions.correct_answer: To protect electrical circuits from overloads

questions.question_text: If a circuit breaker pops in flight, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Reset it immediately and continue to do so if it pops again
Leave it out for the remainder of the flight
Wait a few minutes for it to cool, then reset it once. If it pops again, do not reset.
Land immediately at the nearest airport
questions.correct_answer: Wait a few minutes for it to cool, then reset it once. If it pops again, do not reset.

questions.question_text: What is the primary method of steering the aircraft during taxi?
options: Using the rudder pedals to control the nosewheel, supplemented by differential braking
Using the elevator to lift the nosewheel
questions.correct_answer: Using the rudder pedals to control the nosewheel, supplemented by differential braking

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the oil breather line?
options: To add oil to the engine
To vent excess pressure from the crankcase
questions.correct_answer: To vent excess pressure from the crankcase

questions.question_text: What is the recommended oil type for a Cessna 172N after the initial break-in period?
options: MIL-L-6082 Aviation Grade Straight Mineral Oil

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for a power-off stall recovery?
options: Simultaneously decrease pitch attitude, apply full power, and level the wings
Apply full power first, then lower the nose
Lower the nose, then apply power once airspeed increases
Level the wings, then apply power and lower the nose
questions.correct_answer: Simultaneously decrease pitch attitude, apply full power, and level the wings

questions.question_text: When should the fuel selector valve be operated from a single tank (LEFT or RIGHT) instead of BOTH?
options: During cruising flight to balance fuel levels
It should never be moved from the BOTH position
questions.correct_answer: During cruising flight to balance fuel levels

questions.question_text: What is the consequence of taking off with the fuel selector on a nearly empty tank?
options: The engine will run rough but continue to operate
The engine will fail shortly after takeoff
The fuel will automatically draw from the fuller tank
The fuel gauges will become inaccurate
questions.correct_answer: The engine will fail shortly after takeoff

questions.question_text: What is the recommended action if the door opens in flight?
options: Perform an emergency descent and land
Fly the airplane. Slow down and land to close it, or have a passenger close it if safe.
Ignore it, as it poses no significant aerodynamic hazard
questions.correct_answer: Fly the airplane. Slow down and land to close it, or have a passenger close it if safe.

questions.question_text: What is the effect of extending flaps on the stalling speed?
options: It has no effect on the stalling speed
It only affects the stalling speed at high altitudes

questions.question_text: What is the effect of an increase in weight on stalling speed?
options: It only increases the stalling speed in a turn

questions.question_text: What is the effect of an increased load factor (e.g., in a steep turn) on stalling speed?
options: It has no effect on the stalling speed
It only affects the stalling speed with flaps down

questions.question_text: What is the primary instrument for maintaining pitch attitude during instrument flight?
What is the primary instrument for maintaining bank during instrument flight?
What is the purpose of the 'Alternate Static Source' valve?
options: To provide an alternate source of electricity
To provide an alternate source of vacuum
To provide static pressure from inside the cabin if the external port is blocked
To provide an alternate source of fuel
questions.correct_answer: To provide static pressure from inside the cabin if the external port is blocked

questions.question_text: When using the alternate static source, what is the recommended action regarding cabin vents and windows?
options: Close them to ensure the most stable pressure reading
Only open the pilot's side window
questions.correct_answer: Close them to ensure the most stable pressure reading

questions.question_text: What is the primary cause of 'adverse yaw'?
options: The rudder being deflected too much
The increased drag on the outside wing in a turn
The differential drag produced by the ailerons when initiating a bank
The torque effect of the propeller
questions.correct_answer: The differential drag produced by the ailerons when initiating a bank

questions.question_text: What is 'P-factor'?
options: The tendency for the aircraft to roll left due to propeller torque
The gyroscopic precession effect of the propeller
The asymmetric thrust from the propeller at high angles of attack, causing a yawing moment to the left
The spiraling slipstream hitting the tail
questions.correct_answer: The asymmetric thrust from the propeller at high angles of attack, causing a yawing moment to the left

questions.question_text: P-factor is most pronounced under which conditions?
options: High airspeed, low power, low angle of attack
Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack
High airspeed, high power, low angle of attack
Low airspeed, low power, low angle of attack
questions.correct_answer: Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'bus bar' in the electrical system?
options: To act as a central distribution point for electrical power
To convert AC to DC power
questions.correct_answer: To act as a central distribution point for electrical power

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'true airspeed' (TAS) and 'indicated airspeed' (IAS)?
options: TAS is IAS corrected for instrument error only
TAS is IAS corrected for non-standard pressure and temperature (density altitude)
TAS is always lower than IAS
questions.correct_answer: TAS is IAS corrected for non-standard pressure and temperature (density altitude)

questions.question_text: As altitude increases, what is the relationship between TAS and IAS for a given power setting?
options: TAS will be lower than IAS
TAS will be higher than IAS
questions.correct_answer: TAS will be higher than IAS

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'dihedral' angle of the wings?
What is the procedure for a short-field landing?
options: A steep approach with full flaps, touching down at the minimum possible airspeed on a precise point, and applying maximum braking
A long, shallow approach with no flaps to bleed off speed
A normal approach but with heavy braking after touchdown
A high-speed approach to ensure positive control over the threshold
questions.correct_answer: A steep approach with full flaps, touching down at the minimum possible airspeed on a precise point, and applying maximum braking

questions.question_text: What is the primary risk of landing with excessive airspeed?
options: Stalling the aircraft before the runway
Floating down the runway and potentially overshooting it
A hard landing that could damage the gear
questions.correct_answer: Floating down the runway and potentially overshooting it

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Hobbs meter'?
options: To record the total time the engine has been running
To count the number of landings
questions.correct_answer: To record the total time the engine has been running

questions.question_text: If you are performing a short-field takeoff over a 50-foot obstacle, which speed should be maintained until the obstacle is cleared?
After clearing an obstacle on a short-field takeoff, what is the correct procedure regarding airspeed?
options: Maintain Vx until reaching cruise altitude
Immediately retract flaps and accelerate to cruise speed
Lower the nose to accelerate to Vy for a more efficient climb
Reduce power to 75% and maintain Vx
questions.correct_answer: Lower the nose to accelerate to Vy for a more efficient climb

questions.question_text: You are in cruise flight at 5,500 feet and notice the engine running rough. Applying carburetor heat causes the engine to run even rougher initially, then smooth out with an increase in RPM. What does this indicate?
options: Carburetor ice was present and has been melted
questions.correct_answer: Carburetor ice was present and has been melted

questions.question_text: Why is it recommended to avoid prolonged slips with low fuel in one tank?
options: It can cause the engine to overheat
It can lead to fuel unporting, where the fuel outlet is no longer submerged in fuel, causing engine failure
It can damage the fuel tank bladder
It places excessive stress on the wing structure
questions.correct_answer: It can lead to fuel unporting, where the fuel outlet is no longer submerged in fuel, causing engine failure

questions.question_text: If you must perform a no-flap landing due to an electrical failure, what changes to your landing technique are required?
options: Use a slower approach speed and a shorter runway
Use a faster approach speed and expect a longer landing roll
The landing technique is identical to a normal landing
Use a steeper approach angle to compensate for the lack of drag
questions.correct_answer: Use a faster approach speed and expect a longer landing roll

questions.question_text: What is the primary reason for the RPM drop when checking magnetos during a run-up?
options: The engine is running on only one magneto and a single set of spark plugs, resulting in less efficient combustion
It indicates a malfunction in the checked magneto
The engine is being deliberately overloaded to test its performance
The carburetor heat is activating simultaneously
questions.correct_answer: The engine is running on only one magneto and a single set of spark plugs, resulting in less efficient combustion

questions.question_text: If there is no RPM drop when switching to a single magneto, what is the most likely cause?
options: The engine is running exceptionally well
The ground wire for the unchecked magneto is broken or disconnected, meaning it was never actually turned off
questions.correct_answer: The ground wire for the unchecked magneto is broken or disconnected, meaning it was never actually turned off

questions.question_text: Why is it critical to check 'flight controls free and correct' before takeoff?
options: To ensure the trim is set correctly
To check the hydraulic fluid level
To ensure no control locks are installed and that the controls move in the proper direction
To warm up the control cables
questions.correct_answer: To ensure no control locks are installed and that the controls move in the proper direction

questions.question_text: You are flying at cruise power and notice the oil pressure has dropped to the bottom of the green arc (25 psi). What is the appropriate course of action?
options: Continue to your destination while monitoring the gauge
Increase power to try and raise the pressure
Assume the gauge is faulty and ignore it
Reduce power, land as soon as possible, and prepare for a potential engine failure
questions.correct_answer: Reduce power, land as soon as possible, and prepare for a potential engine failure

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the propeller's diameter specifications (e.g., Max 75 inches, Min 74 inches)?
options: It indicates the range of adjustable pitch
It defines the limits for repairs; a blade cannot be filed shorter than the minimum
It is the required diameter for different altitudes
It is the difference between the M and N model propellers
questions.correct_answer: It defines the limits for repairs; a blade cannot be filed shorter than the minimum

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of having two separate magnetos and two spark plugs per cylinder?
options: To provide redundancy and improved combustion efficiency
To allow the engine to run on lower octane fuel
To reduce the engine's operating temperature
questions.correct_answer: To provide redundancy and improved combustion efficiency

questions.question_text: What is the primary aerodynamic effect of ground effect?
options: A significant increase in induced drag, requiring more power for takeoff
A reduction in induced drag, causing the aircraft to float during landing
questions.correct_answer: A reduction in induced drag, causing the aircraft to float during landing

questions.question_text: You are on a long final approach and notice you are low. What is the correct way to adjust your glide path?
options: Lower the nose to gain speed, then pull back
Add power to decrease the rate of descent, and adjust pitch to maintain airspeed
Raise the nose to stretch the glide
questions.correct_answer: Add power to decrease the rate of descent, and adjust pitch to maintain airspeed

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between maneuvering speed (Va) and aircraft weight?
options: Va is not affected by weight
Va is always a fixed value regardless of weight

questions.question_text: Why must abrupt control movements be avoided above maneuvering speed (Va)?
options: The engine cannot handle the rapid changes in airflow
The flight controls may become ineffective
The aircraft could exceed its structural load limits
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft could exceed its structural load limits

questions.question_text: What is the primary force that opposes thrust?
What is the primary force that opposes lift?
In straight-and-level, unaccelerated flight, what is the relationship between the four forces of flight?
options: Thrust is greater than drag, and lift is greater than weight
Thrust equals drag, and lift equals weight
Thrust is less than drag, and lift is less than weight
Thrust equals lift, and drag equals weight
questions.correct_answer: Thrust equals drag, and lift equals weight

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'density altitude'?
options: The altitude shown on the altimeter
The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature
The actual height of the aircraft above ground level
The height of the aircraft above sea level
questions.correct_answer: The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature

questions.question_text: What is the primary reason for using flaps during takeoff and landing?
options: To increase the aircraft's maximum speed
To increase the wing's lift and drag, allowing for slower and steeper approaches
To improve roll control at low speeds
To reduce the structural load on the wings
questions.correct_answer: To increase the wing's lift and drag, allowing for slower and steeper approaches

questions.question_text: What is 'pressure altitude'?
options: The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to the current local setting
The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 inches of mercury
The true height above sea level
questions.correct_answer: The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 inches of mercury

questions.question_text: What is the correct response to a 'LOW VOLTAGE' annunciation in flight?
options: Turn on all electrical equipment to increase the load
Turn off the alternator, reduce electrical load, and land as soon as practical
Cycle the master switch several times
Ignore it unless the battery dies
questions.correct_answer: Turn off the alternator, reduce electrical load, and land as soon as practical

questions.question_text: A stall is caused by:
options: The wing exceeding its critical angle of attack
questions.correct_answer: The wing exceeding its critical angle of attack

questions.question_text: What is the primary flight control that creates and controls the 'angle of attack'?
What is the purpose of the 'ground' wire on a magneto's ignition switch?
options: To provide power to the magneto
To disable or 'kill' the magneto by grounding the primary circuit
questions.correct_answer: To disable or 'kill' the magneto by grounding the primary circuit

questions.question_text: What is the standard entry procedure for a traffic pattern at a non-towered airport?
options: A straight-in approach to the landing runway
A 45-degree entry to the downwind leg at pattern altitude
A direct entry to the base leg
Crossing over the field 500 feet above pattern altitude
questions.correct_answer: A 45-degree entry to the downwind leg at pattern altitude

questions.question_text: What is the standard traffic pattern altitude (TPA) for a piston-engine aircraft?
What is the primary risk associated with 'wake turbulence'?
options: Engine failure due to disturbed air
Loss of control due to powerful wingtip vortices
questions.correct_answer: Loss of control due to powerful wingtip vortices

questions.question_text: To avoid wake turbulence from a large aircraft that has just taken off, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Rotate at the same point as the large aircraft and climb above its flight path
Rotate prior to the large aircraft's rotation point and climb above its flight path
Rotate after the large aircraft's rotation point and remain below its flight path
Wait at least 10 minutes before taking off
questions.correct_answer: Rotate prior to the large aircraft's rotation point and climb above its flight path

questions.question_text: To avoid wake turbulence from a large aircraft that has just landed, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Land prior to the large aircraft's touchdown point
Land beyond the large aircraft's touchdown point
Land in the same spot as the large aircraft
questions.correct_answer: Land beyond the large aircraft's touchdown point

questions.question_text: What is the primary source of cabin heat in a Cessna 172?
options: A shroud around the engine exhaust muffler
Bleed air from the vacuum pump
A combustion heater in the tail cone
questions.correct_answer: A shroud around the engine exhaust muffler

questions.question_text: What is a potential hazard associated with using cabin heat?
options: Carbon monoxide poisoning if the exhaust shroud is cracked
questions.correct_answer: Carbon monoxide poisoning if the exhaust shroud is cracked

questions.question_text: If the pitot tube becomes blocked but the static port remains clear, which instrument will be affected and how?
options: The altimeter will freeze at the altitude of the blockage
The airspeed indicator will act like an altimeter
The vertical speed indicator will show a constant climb
The airspeed indicator will drop to zero
questions.correct_answer: The airspeed indicator will act like an altimeter

questions.question_text: If the static port becomes blocked, which instruments will give inaccurate readings?
options: Airspeed indicator, attitude indicator, and directional gyro
Airspeed indicator, altimeter, and vertical speed indicator
Tachometer, oil pressure gauge, and fuel gauges
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed indicator, altimeter, and vertical speed indicator

questions.question_text: An aircraft loaded with a center of gravity that is too far aft will exhibit what flight characteristics?
options: Difficulty in raising the nose for takeoff and landing
Increased longitudinal stability and slow cruise speeds
Instability, making it difficult to recover from a stall
questions.correct_answer: Instability, making it difficult to recover from a stall

questions.question_text: An aircraft loaded with a center of gravity that is too far forward will exhibit what flight characteristics?
options: Very easy to flare for landing
Difficulty in raising the nose, especially during takeoff and landing
questions.correct_answer: Difficulty in raising the nose, especially during takeoff and landing

questions.question_text: What is the effect of high density altitude on takeoff performance?
options: Shorter takeoff roll and increased climb rate
Longer takeoff roll and reduced climb rate
Shorter takeoff roll and reduced climb rate
questions.correct_answer: Longer takeoff roll and reduced climb rate

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for recovering from a spin?
options: Power to full, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator forward
Power to idle, ailerons with the spin, rudder neutral, and elevator back
Power to idle, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator control forward to break the stall
Power to full, flaps to 20 degrees, and pull back firmly on the elevator
questions.correct_answer: Power to idle, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator control forward to break the stall

questions.question_text: Are intentional spins permitted in a Cessna 172N when operating in the Normal Category?
options: Yes, but only with flaps retracted
Only if the aircraft is below 2000 lbs

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the elevator trim?
options: To move the elevator directly for pitch control
To relieve control pressures and maintain a desired pitch attitude
To assist in banking the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: To relieve control pressures and maintain a desired pitch attitude

What is the unusable fuel quantity in a long-range Cessna 172 tank configuration?
What is the primary difference in the engine of a Cessna 172M versus a 172N?
options: The 172M has a lower horsepower rating (150 hp vs 160 hp)
questions.correct_answer: The 172M has a lower horsepower rating (150 hp vs 160 hp)

questions.question_text: What is the significance of a steady red light from a control tower to an aircraft in flight?
options: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling
questions.correct_answer: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling

questions.question_text: What is the significance of a flashing green light from a control tower to an aircraft on the ground?
options: Return to starting point on airport

questions.question_text: In the 'Engine Failures During Flight' restart procedure, what is the final memory item listed?

What is the maximum baggage weight allowed in Area 1 (station 82 to 108)?
What is the recommended action if the engine starts during a ground fire procedure?
options: Increase power to 1700 RPM for a few minutes
Reduce power to idle and wait for fire services
questions.correct_answer: Increase power to 1700 RPM for a few minutes

questions.question_text: During an engine fire in flight, if the fire is not extinguished, the checklist recommends increasing glide speed. Why?
options: To get to a landing spot faster
To find an airspeed that provides an incombustible mixture
To cool the engine more rapidly
questions.correct_answer: To find an airspeed that provides an incombustible mixture

questions.question_text: In the event of a cabin fire, after switching off the master, what is the next step?
options: Close all vents and cabin heat/air
questions.correct_answer: Close all vents and cabin heat/air
